pageTitle: International Students Support Job Creation and Contribute $24 Billion to U.S. Economy -- WASHINGTON, Nov. 12, 2013 /PRNewswire-USNewswire/ --
TableContextTimeStampBeforeTable: {6433=WASHINGTON, Nov. 12, 2013 /PRNewswire-USNewswire/ -- The 819,644 international students and their families at universities and colleges across the country supported 313,000 jobs and contributed $24 billion to the U.S. economy during the 2012-2013 academic year, according to new NAFSA findings. This is a 6.2% increase in job support and creation and a nearly 10% increase in dollars contributed to the economy from the previous academic year., 1583=The economic analysis was conducted for NAFSA by Jason Baumgartner, director of information services with Indiana University-Bloomington's Office of International Services, using enrollment data from the Institute of International Education's Open Doors 2013 report, which is produced in partnership with the Department of State's Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs, and using tuition and expense data from the Department of Education's National Center of Educational Statistics Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System., 207=Contributions to House Leadership Congressional Districts by International Students and their Dependents (2012-13)}
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {15185=NAFSA's analysis on study abroad trends is based on data from the Institute of International Education's Open Doors 2013 report, which is produced in partnership with the Department of State's Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs, and data from the Department of Education's National Center of Educational Statistics., 4944=Top Ten U.S. Congressional Districts by Total Dollars Contributed by International Students and their Dependents (2012-13), 10294=Vacant (Special election to fill seat scheduled for Dec. 10), 123664=Copyright © 2015 PR Newswire Association LLC. Powered by Clickability., 14791=NAFSA's new report provides a breakdown of the percentage of college students in each state who studied abroad in 2011-2012, allowing institutions and state leaders to gauge how they compare with national trends.}
textBeforeTable: Contributions to House Leadership Congressional Districts by International Students and their Dependents (2012-13) Access NAFSA's International Student Economic Value Tool to view ten-year trends as well as detailed analysis available by region, state, and congressional district. The economic analysis was conducted for NAFSA by Jason Baumgartner, director of information services with Indiana University-Bloomington's Office of International Services, using enrollment data from the Institute of International Education's Open Doors 2013 report, which is produced in partnership with the Department of State's Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs, and using tuition and expense data from the Department of Education's National Center of Educational Statistics Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System. In addition to the economic benefits international students bring to the United States, they contribute incalculable academic and cultural value to U.S. colleges and universities and to local communities. International students build bridges between the United States and other countries, bring global perspectives into U.S. classrooms and research labs, and support U.S. innovation through science and engineering coursework, making it possible for U.S. colleges and universities to offer these courses to U.S. students.
